This is a silly game with some funny jokes that reek of the early 2010s. If that's all you want, then I recommend it. But as a game? Something to sit down and play after a long day? No.

Poorly optimized, questionable controls, and the humor gets grating after a while. The game's 'quirks' are funny at first, but then gets boring.

When Roger Ebert boldly declared that "Video games can never be art" in 2010, he CLEARLY never could have anticipated this artistic masterpiece. Goat Simulator sits in the cannon alongside the greatest western artistic works such as the Sistine Chapel, the Mona Lisa, The Divine Comedy, Romeo & Juliet, Da Vinci's The Last Supper, Skibidi Toilet, Dostoevsky's Crimes And Punishment, and the cinematic works of the great filmmakers such as Tarkovsky, Kubrick, and Lynch as well as The Minecraft Movie. It really taps into the cultural zeitgeist of being a human living under late stage capitalism and the painful struggles for survival that the poor and working middle classes face when the goat says "BAAAAAAA!!!!!" We feel his RAGE living in a system designed to keep us down, as similar to the lyrics of The Smashing Pumpkins in their song "Bullet with Butterfly Wings" which says "Despite all my rage, I am still just a rat in a cage."


When David Lynch (RIP) said “Ideas are like fish. If you want to catch little fish, you can stay in the shallow water. But if you want to catch the big fish, you've got to go deeper. Down deep, the fish are more powerful and more pure", he was CLEARLY talking about Goat Simulator (2014), which is the artistic biproduct of a team not afraid to take true risks and dive into those deeper more serene artistic waters. 

Someday, Goat Simulator will be taught as a MANDATORY course in art schools around the world. A masterpiece of Dadaist satire that Duchamp would have been proud of and thought of as natural the spiritual successor to his groundbreaking Urinal masterwork known as "Fountain" from 1917. 

This PROFOUND insight into the human condition really elevates Goat Simulator to the highest of literary prose. 
I cannot recommend Goat Simulator enough!
